name: 1,1'-thiocarbonyldi-2(1h)-pyridone
Reason: 1,1'-thiocarbonyldi-2(1H)-pyridone has a melting point that we can compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight. Additionally, the pyridine ring introduces additional rigidity and hydrogen bonding potential, estimated at around +20°C. The methyl group reduces the melting point due to the reduced symmetry and molecular volume, estimated at around -5°C. The carbonyl group introduces additional rigidity and hydrogen bonding potential, estimated at around +20°C. The thiocarbonyl group introduces additional rigidity and hydrogen bonding potential, estimated at around +10°C.
